note_models.name: Basic

fields: What are the duties of SOC Tier 1 (Alert Analyst)?
monitor incoming alerts, confirm incident has occurred, and escalate to Tier 2.
What role monitors incoming alerts, confirms the incident, and escalates?
What are the responsibilities of SOC Tier 2 (Incident Responder)?
Who in the SOC does deep investigation and advises remediation?
What are the duties of SOC Tier 3 (SME/Hunter)?
These experts trace and disect malware, search for potential threats, and implement detection tools.
What SOC role implements detection tools, searches for potential threats and disects malware?
What are the duties of SOC Manager?
Manage all resources in the SOC.  Act as a point of contact.
In the SOC who acts as a point of contact and manages all SOC resources?
What is stored in the HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG hive?  (Windows Registry)
Data for the current hardware profile
Which Windows Registry hive has current hardware profile data?
What is stored in the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE hive?  (Windows Registry)
Which Windows Registry hive has system-related data?
What is stored in the HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT hive?  (Windows Registry)
Which Windows Registry hive has data for Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) registrations?
What is stored in the HKEY_USERS hive?  (Windows Registry)
data for all users on the host
Which Windows Registry hive has data about the users on the host?
What is stored in the HKEY_CURRENT_USER hive?  (Windows Registry)
data concerning the currently logged in user
Which Windows Registry hive has data about the current logged in user?
What are the elements of an Security Operations Center (SOC)?
Process, Technology, and People form what?
What is the purpose of Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)?
Manage remote computers.  Collect information and change settings.
In Windows what is used to manage remote computers?
For Linux filesystem permissions what is the difference between the execute permission being set on a file versus a directory?
Execute on a file allows you to run it like a program.  Execute on a directory allows you to enter the directory.
What Linux filesystem permission behaves differently between files and directories?
Where are authentication related events stored in Debian-based distros?
Which distros use auth.log for authentication related events?
Where are authentication related events stored in RedHat-based distros?
Which distros use /var/log/secure for authentication related events?
What is the current default filesystem on Mac OS?
Where is the Apple File System (APFS) used?
It is the current default on Mac OS.
In a SIEM, what is the purpose of correlation?
Examine events from multiple sensors to speed detection.
What SIEM function examines events from multiple sensors to speed detection?
In a SIEM, what is the purpose of aggregation?
Reduce event volume by removing duplicates.
What SIEM function reduces volume by removing duplicates?
What transport protocol does TACACS+ use?
What transport protocol does RADIUS use?
Which authentication protocol encrypts the entire packet?
Which authentication protocol encrypts the password?
What does the 802.11 beacon frame include?
802.11: If the AP doesn't send beacon frames, what mode must the client use?
802.11: What is the difference between client-side Active and Passive mode?
In Active mode the client will try to connect to a hidden SSID.
In the Hierarchical Network Design what is the purpose of the Distribution layer?
Implement policy-based connectivity.  Acts as a control boundary.
Which layer in the Hierarchical Network Design model acts as a control boundary and provides policy-based connectivity?
What is the difference between physical and logical topologies?
Physical refers to physical links.  Logical refers to how frames flow between nodes.
Which network topology is concerned with how frames flow between nodes?
What is a Local Route Interface?
A route that is added when the interfaces comes up.  In IPv4 it is a /32 route.
When an interface comes up, what IPv4/32 route is added?
A phishing attack that uses the telephone.
What phishing attack uses the telephone?
When an attacker lies about one thing to get access to something else.
What is the attack called when the attacker lies about one thing to gain access to something else?
What are the components of a worm?
Together an enabling vulnerability, propagation mechanism, and payload are components of what attack?
An attack that targets weaknesses in authentication and access.
Which attack targets weaknesses in passwords or trust relationships?
What is the purpose of an access attack?
Privilege escallation, system access, data retrieval
What type of attack would be used to escalate privileges, gain access, or retrieve data?
Define the term: key length or key size
It is the length in bits of a cryptographic key.
What term defines the length of a cryptographic key?
The number of possible keys of a given length
What term represents the number of possible keys of a given length?
What is the DNS Shadowing attack?
An attacker compromises a parent domain then create multiple subdomains.
In what attack will subdomains be created after compromising a parent domain?
Which group offers Automated Indicator Sharing (AIS)?
What cyber threat indicators does the DHS share?
Why has the Security Artichoke replaced the Security Onion?
With each leaf of the artichoke that is compromised, more information becomes available to the attacker.
The idea of chipping away at layers of security to gain more information is illustrated in what analogy?
What is the purpose of STIX?
To standardize language for sharing cyberthreat intelligence
What standardizes language for sharing cyberthreat intelligence?
What is the purpose of Trusted Automated eXchange of Indicator Information (TAXII)?
It's a protocol used to share cyberthreat intelligence (like STIX).
What protocol can share cyberthreat intelligence?
Trusted Automated eXchange of Indicator Information (TAXII)
DES, 3DES, and AES are examples of what kind of encryption algorithms?
What class of PKI Certificate is used for testing?
What is the purpose of a PKI Class 0 certificate?
Describe what happens as PKI Class numbers increase.
The identity verification becomes more rigorous.
As PKI identity verification becomes more rigorous, what happens to the certificate class?
What is the difference between hashing and signing?
Hashing will detect accidental changes only.  Signing will also detect deliberate changes.
What can be used to detect accidental changes vs deliberate changes?
Hashing: accidental.  Signing: accidental and deliberate
What are the elements of secure communication?
Data integrity, non-repudiation, data confidentiality, and origin authentication
Together; data integrity, non-repudiation, data confidentiality, and origin authentication form what?
What algorithms can be used to generate and verify signatures?
What are RSA, DSA, and ECDSA capable of?
Describe three methods antimalware programs can detect viruses.
Describe the differences between Signatures, Heuristics, and Behavior for virus detection.
Signature: uses hashes.  Heuristics: looking for suspect code in an application or other features.  Behaviour: modifying system files, accessing botnets.
What is a host-based intrusion detection (and prevention) system?
Any combination of antimalware running on the host itself.
Section 10.1.2.2 & CCNA CyberOps SECFND OCG Ch 4
What is it called when a combination of antimalware is running on a host?
Section 10.1.2.2 & CCNA CyberOps SECFND OCG Ch 4
What are three activities for identifying vulnerabilities?
Risk Analysis, Vulnerability Assessment, Penetration Testing
What is the purpose of risk analysis, vulnerability assessment, and penetration testing?
What are the Exploitability Metrics in the Base Metric Group of CVSS?
Attack Vector, Attack Complexity, Privileges Required, User Interaction, Scope.
What do the following metrics belong to? Attack Vector, Attack Complexity, Privileges Required, User Interaction, Scope.
Exploitability Metrics in the Base Metric Group of CVSS
What are the steps in the Vulnerability Management Life Cycle?
Discover, Prioritize assets, Assess, Report, Remediate, Verify
Where are these steps found?  Discover, Prioritize assets, Assess, Report, Remediate, Verify
What is the name of a front-end for Snort(IDS)?
A front-end for Snort (IDS) to increase readability and searchability.

Network Behaviour Analysis (NBA) and Network Behaviour Anomoly Detection (NBAD) are techniquest that analyse network metrics (Netflow/IPFix) and employ statistical models to detect statistically significant differences.
What can be used to detect statistically significant differences in network metrics (Netflow/IPFix)?
Network Behaviour Analysis (NBA) and Network Behaviour Anomoly Detection (NBAD).
How is Syslog's Priority(PRI) field defined?
Priority is an 8-bit value where the highest 5 bits represent the facility (32 possibilities) and the lowest 3 bits represent the severity (8 possibilities).
What Syslog field is made from concatenating a 5-bit field and a 3-bit field?
Syslog priority.  Top 5 bits for Facility.  Bottom 3 bits for Severity.
What does an asterisk of period prefixing the timestamp of a syslog message mean?
There is a problem with NTP.  The timestamp may not be accurate.
How does syslog indicate there is a problem with NTP?
Prefix the timestamp of a syslog message with a period or asterisk.
What are the different logs inside the Event Viewer for a MS Windows host?
What platform has Application, System, Setup, and Security logs?
What is the term for evidence in its original state?
Evidence that supports an assertion that is developed from best evidence
What is the term that describes evidence that supports an assertion?
Evidence that helps establish a hypothesis
What is the term that describes evidence that helps establish a hypothesis?
What is the NIST 800-64 forensic process?
What process includes Collection, Examination, Analysis, and Reporting?
In NIST 800-64 how is Collection defined?
The identification of potential sources of forensic data and acquisition, handling, and storage of that data.
In NIST 800-64, what term describes the identification of potential sources of forensic data and acquisition, handling, and storage of that data?
In NIST 800-64 how is Examination defined?
Assessing and extrating relevant information from the collected data.
In NIST 800-64, what term describes assessing and extracting relevant information from the collected data?
In NIST 800-64 how is Analysis defined?
In NIST 800-64, what term describes drawing conclusions from forensic data?
In NIST 800-64 how is Reporting defined?
Preparing and presenting information that resulted from the analysis.
In NIST 800-64, what term describes preparing and presenting information that resulted from the analysis of forensic data?
In the Sguil UI, what do the 'ST' and 'CNT' columns indicate?
ST - Status where RT means 'Realtime' and the color indicates the priority level.  CNT is the 'count' of the number of times this event has been detected.
Where can you find the number of occurences of an alert and their priority in the Sguil UI?
What are the steps in the Cyber Kill Chain?
Reconnaissance, Weaponization, Delivery, Exploitation, Installation, CnC, Action on Objectives.
What are these steps part of?  Reconnaissance, Weaponization, Delivery, Exploitation, Installation, CnC, Action on Objectives.
For the Cyber Kill Chain; define Weaponization
Pairing remote malware with a backdoor to create a payload
In the Cyber Kill Chain, which step pairs remote malware with a backdoor to create a payload?
What are the core features of the Diamond Model?  Draw it.
Adversary and Victim are top and bottom.  Infrastructure and Capability are on the sides and connected.
Adversary, Victim, Infrastructure and Capacility are all parts of what model?
What are the meta features of the Diamond Model?
Timestamp Phase Result Direction Methodology Resouces
What do these features belong to?  Timestamp Phase Result Direction Methodology Resouces
They are META features of the Diamond Model
What is the purpose of VERIS?
The Vocabulary for Event Recording and Incident Sharing (VERIS) provides metrics for describing security incidents.
What provides metrics for describing security incidents?
What are the top-level elements of VERIS?
Impact Assessment, Discovery & Reponse, Incident Description, Victim Demographics, Incident Tracking
What do the following elements pertain to?  Impact Assessment, Discovery & Reponse, Incident Description, Victim Demographics, Incident Tracking
Protected Health Information.  Any information regarding the provision of health care or status of an individual.
What term and abbreviation is used to refer to information about the provision of health care or status of an individual?
It's a framework (API) that ties into Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) to facilitate data sharing to other network devices.
What is the name of the framework that ties into Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) to facilitate data sharing to other network devices.
What is the preferred port and protocol for DNS?
UDP/53 for standard queries, TCP/53 for zone transfers.
What uses UDP and TCP port 53?
What term is defined as the possibility of a security incident happening?
Define 'Risk' in terms used within Cyber Security
The possibility of a security incident occurring.
Why is the FirePower Management Center (FMC) able to export HTML, PDF, and CSV files?
To share instrusion data with other entities.
In the Firepower Management Center (FMC), how can you share intrustion data with other entities?
Export HTML, PDF, or CSV files.
Which ISO standard covers general risk management; principles and guidelines for managing risk?
General risk management; principles and guidelines for managing risk.
It is the path used by a malicious actor to perform an attack.
What is the term for the path used by a malicious actor to perform an attack?
The process of exploiting in sequence so that one vulnerability exposes the next.
What is the term for exploiting vulnerabilties in sequence so that one exploit exposes a vulnerability for another?
Who makes the access decision in a Discretionary Access Control model?
In what model does the object owner make the access decision?
CloudLock is a Data Loss Prevention product for cloud environments.
What Cisco product does Data Loss Prevention in cloud environments?
Why would an attacker use encryption?
How can malware evade IDS/IPS fingerprinting?
A collection of exploits that are frequently served from web servers.
What is the term that describes a collection of expoits that are often served from web servers?
What types of information is available in Cisco ISE reports?
Reports related to authentication, RADIUS, admin logins, guest access.
What product can generate reports related to authentication, admin logins, guess access, and RADIUS?
Can an IDS help to mitigate an attack?  Explain.
In Promiscuous mode an IDS can work with other devices to request that action is taken to block traffic.
What device in what mode can work with other network equipment (like firewalls) to request that malicious traffic is blocked?
For Configuration Management, where are configuration records kept?
What is kept in the Configuration Management Database (CMDB)?
A collection of procedures and operations performed by sysadmins, netops, and security professionals.
What is the term for a collection of procedures and operations performed by sysadmins, netops and security professionals?
How is effectiveness measured for a Runbook?
Mean time: to repair, between failures, to discover a security incident, to contain or mitigate a security incident.  Effective Runbooks also automate the provisioning of IT resources.
MTBF, MTTR, Mean time to discover and contain a security incident are all metrics to measure the effectiveness of what?
When a process completes execution, releases associated memory and resources but remains in the process table.
What is the term for a process that has released all resources but remains in the process table?
An orphan process is a process whose parent process has died.
What do you call a process whose parent process has died?
What are the Public Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS)?
They are a set of protocols (not algorithms) for handling Public Key Cryptosystems
What is the name of the protocols for handling public key cryptosystems?
With Mandatory Access Control how is the access decision made?
The OS enforces policy based on security labels.
What Access Control Model uses the OS to enforce policy based on security labels?
It is a type of Spear phishing that targets executives and high profile users.
What term is used to refer to spear phishing that targets executives and high profile users?
How does a Next Generation Firewall (NGFW) differ from a tradional stateful firewall?
NGFWs are application-aware and able to do intrusion prevention.
What type of firewalls are application-aware and able to do intrusion prevention?
How are access decisions made with the Attribute-based Access Control (ABAC) model?
Decisions are based on the attributes of the subject, object and environment.
In which access control model are decisions made based on the subject, object, and environment?
Google Chromium, Java JVM, HTML5 sandbox attribute in iFrames
What do Google Chromium, Java JVM, and HTML5 allow?
Describe the administrative control 'separation of duties.'
A single individual should not perform all critical duties.
Having no single indivudual able to perform all critical tasks is an example of what administrative control?
What is the purpose of the Identification field in the IPv4 Header?
The Identification field is used to uniquely identify a group of fragments of a single IP datagram.
What IPv4 Header field is used to uniquely group a set of fragments belonging to a single IP datagram?
What is the difference between iterative and recursive DNS queries?
Recursive queries are sent from a host (resolver) to a server.  Iterative queries are send between servers.
What type of DNS query is sent from a host to a server?  From a server to another server?
Collaborative Research Into Threats (CRITs) is a feed (open source) for threat data.
Name an open source feed for threat data.
In Mandatory Access Control what are the parts of the security label?
In Mandatory Access Control what do classification and category form?
What is a DNS cache poisoning attack / DNS spoofing attack?
It is an attack that puts false information on a DNS resolver to forward victims to a malicious site.
What is the name of the attack that falsifies data on a DNS resolver to forward victims to a malicious site?
What techniques can attackers use to avoid detection by NIDS that may still be detected by HIDS?
Can attackers use encryption and fragmentation to evade NIDS or HIDS?
What is the name of Cisco's Managed Security Service?
What is Cisco's Active Threat Analytics?
It is a managed security service (SOC).
When an incident is detected, what should be investigated during scoping?
What is affected.  What originated the incident.  How the incident is occurring.
When should these questions be asked: what is affected; what is originating the incident; how is the incident occurring?
During the initial scoping of an incident.
What are the elements of an incident response plan?

Mission
Strategies and goals
senior management approval
organization approach to incident response
communications plan
metrics for measuring the incident response capability and its effectiveness
roadmap for maturing the incident response capability
how the program fits into the overall organization

What do these elements form?
Mission
Strategies and goals
senior management approval
organization approach to incident response
communications plan
metrics for measuring the incident response capability and its effectiveness
roadmap for maturing the incident response capability
how the program fits into the overall organization
What is the purpose of a National CSIRT or CERT?
Provide vulnerability information, awareness training, best practices.
What organization protects citizens by providing vulnerability information, awareness training and best practices?
A sign that an attacker may be preparing to cause an incident.
What is the term used to describe a sign that an attacker may be preparing to cause an incident
In which type of analysis is all analytical data known beforehand?
Facts are known or obtained about the incident.  Deterministic Analysis uses this known data.
What Analysis method is performed when something has likely occured?
What is used for Probabilistic Analysis?
Data that is assumed to be accurate.  The conclusions are also probabilistic.
What are the policies and procedures a company CSIRT is responsible for?

Incident classification and handling
information classification and protection
information dissemination
record retention and destruction
acceptable use of encryption
engaging with external groups

In a corporate environment what group is responsible for the following?  Incident classification and handling, information classification and protection, information dissemination, record retention and destruction, acceptable use of encryption, engaging with external groups.
What is a well known Coordination Center?
The CERT Division of the Software Engineering Institute.
What is the CERT Division of the Software Engineering Institute known for?
What is included in the NetFlow 5-Tuple?
Src IP, Dst IP, Src Port, Dest Port, Protocol.
Where is this 5-Tuple used?  Src IP, Dst IP, Src Port, Dest Port, Protocol
The process of developing and testing how an attack will be executed
What term describes the process of developing and testing how an attack will be executed
What are the three broad categories of cybersecurity investigations?
Public, Private, and Individual are three broad categories of what?
Which CVSS Exploitability metrics can have a value of 'None'?
What value is common in CVSS Exploitability metrics for Privilege Required and User Interaction?
Both can have a value of 'None'
It limits the impact of the incident and allows for time to develop a remediation strategy.
What limits the impact of an incident and allows for time to develop a remediation strategy?
What is the term for remediating network and affected systems and trying trying to reveal the responsible threat actor?
The process of remediation and trying to reveal the threat actor.
